{{also|suden}} ==German== ===Etymology=== From {{etyl|gml|de}} and {{etyl|dum|de}} {{m|gml|sūden}}. The form is already attested in {{cog|gmh|sūden}}, which replaces native Middle High German {{m|gml|sunden}} from {{etyl|goh|-}} {{m|de|sundan}}. However, the modern form with a preserved monophthong must be directly from Middle Low German or Middle Dutch. The latter's influence is seen in the umlaut (compare the Middle Dutch pronunciation of ''-ū-'' [yː]). All these forms are from {{etyl|gem-pro|de}} {{m|gem-pro|*sunþanē}}, an adverb meaning “from the south”. The original Proto-Germanic noun {{m|gem-pro|*sunþrą}}, whence English {{m|en|south}} and German {{m|de|Süd}}, has always been restricted chiefly to compounds in continental West Germanic. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|de|/ˈzyːdən/}} * {{audio|de|De-Süden.ogg|audio (Germany)}} * {{audio|de|De-at-Süden.ogg|audio (Austria)}} ===Noun=== {{de-noun|m|Südens|-}} # [[south]] (direction) # [[south]] (region) ====Declension==== {{de-decl-noun-m|s|n=sg}} ====Antonyms==== * {{l|de|Norden}} ====Related terms==== * {{l|de|Südpol}} * {{l|de|Südhalbkugel}} * {{l|de|Südeuropa}} * {{l|de|Südamerika}} * {{l|de|Süddeutschland}} * {{l|de|südlich}} * {{l|de|Südwind}} * {{l|de|Osten}} * {{l|de|Westen}} ===See also=== {{compass|n=Nord|ne=Nordost|e=Ost|se=Südost|s=Süd|sw=Südwest|w=West|nw=Nordwest|lang=de}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:Duden}} [[Category:de:Compass points]] ---- ==Luxembourgish== ===Etymology=== From {{etyl|de|lb}} {{m|de|Süden}}, from {{etyl|dum|lb}} {{m|dum|suden}}. ===Pronunciation=== * {{IPA|lb|/ˈzyːdən/}} ===Noun=== {{lb-noun|m|-}} # [[south]] ===See also=== * {{l|lb|Norden}} * {{l|lb|Osten}} * {{l|lb|Westen}} [[Category:lb:Compass points]]
